content:
AUSTRALIA

Bluescope Steel (BSL AT) - Co. engaged with ACCC on cartel allegations. (Newswires)

Downer EDI (DOW AT) - Co. unit Spotless Group is expected to divest laundry unit. (AFR)

Helloworld (HLO AT) - Co. is to acquire Traveledge Group. (Newswires)

Macquarie Media (MRN AT) - Nine Entertainment (NEC AT) confirms it raised its stake in the Co. to around 87.1% from Prev. 54.4%. (Newswires)

Treasury Wine Estates (TWE AT) - Co. is targeting 25% market share in Australia and is seeking to expand by volume and value in Asia. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT) - AIG is said to be interested in Co.’s life insurance unit. (Newswires)

Financials - Moody’s said Australia banks’ profitability is likely to weaken but added that asset quality and capital support the stable outlook. (Newswires)

Other News - AMP (AMP AT), Fortescue Metals (FMG AT) and Harvey Norman (HVN AT) are reportedly among dozens of leading domestic companies set to reduce dividends. (The Australian)

 

JAPAN

Calsonic Kansei (7248 JT) - Magneti Marelli is to combine Calsonic Kansei with another auto parts subsidiary in which it then seeks to conduct an IPO. (Newswires)

Hitachi (6501 JT) - Co. is said to raise JPY 1tln through loans and bonds by May 2022. (Nikkei)

Honda (7267 JT) - Co. and SoftBank (9984 JT) are to launch a motorbike sharing service in Japan, while Honda is also reported to exit diesel cars in Europe amid shift to electrics by 2025. (Nikkei)

Mitsubishi Corp (8058 JT) - Co. Petro-Diamond unit is to record loss of around USD 320mln from trading of crude oil derivates and noted that a worker made unauthorized trades. (Newswires)

Nippon Express (9062 JT) - Co. to acquire 22% stake in Future Supply Chain Solutions for INR 2.5bln. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. and former Chairman and CEO Ghosn will pay a combined USD 16mln to settle fraud charges with SEC that alleged they hid compensation to the former chief. (Nikkei)

Nissha Printing (7915 JT) - Co. is to record one-time gain of JPY 5.0bln from sale of its plant. (Newswires)

SoftBank Group (9984 JT) - Co. is looking at about 40 companies in Brazil for potential investment. (Newswires)

Sompo Holdings (8630 JT) - Co. sees JPY 110bln in losses from Typhoon Faxai. (Newswires)

Tokyo Electron (8035 JT) - Co. announced that it has decided to merge 2 of is US unit’s subsidiaries. (Newswires)

Tokyo Gas (9531 JT) - Co. lost 370k customers in January to June. (Nikkei)

Energy - Japan's public and private sectors plan to invest USD 10bln on LNG related projects such as processing plants, receiving terminals and power generation. (Nikkei)

Other News - Japan and US may fail to sign a trade agreement this week amid disagreement regarding auto tariffs. (NYT)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co. is to set up a USD 4bln driverless JV with Aptiv next year. (Nikkei)

Korea Gas (036460 KS) - Co. signs a 15-yr purchase agreement to buy LNG from BP beginning 2025. (Newswires)

Lotte Corp (004990 KS) - Co. is to sell KRW 333bln stake in Lotte Capital. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. is said to invest KRW 13tln into next generation displays, while it was also reported the Galaxy Fold will be available in the US from Friday following several months of delay. (Newswires)

Other News - US President Trump said a meeting with North Korea's Kim Jong-un could come soon and that the US is getting along well with North Korea , while he added maybe we will be able to make a deal or maybe not and will discuss North Korea missile launches with South Korean President Moon. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated that China Vice Premier Liu He will visit next week for discussions and confirmed the Chinese delegation visit to US farm states was delayed at US request. (Newswires)

US Agriculture Secretary Perdue said the US asked China to purchase more than 20mln tonnes of soybeans but noted there were no commitments from China last week and that he did not know why the farm visits were cancelled. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU 

UK government official said PM Johnson was clear in meeting with EU's Tusk that a Northern Ireland only backstop was not a solution the UK could accept, while the official added we believe we have put forward detailed proposals to get the process moving along and want to see that the EU are ready to engage seriously with the ideas we put forward. (Newswires)

EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier said UK proposals on the border between the two countries of Ireland is unacceptable and that it is hard to see how a solution that meets all the objectives of the backstop can be met. Conversely, German Foreign Minister Maas said the proposals presented by Britain last week were a step forward and still thinks an orderly Brexit is possible. (Newswires)

ECB President Draghi said we need a coherent economic strategy in the Euro area which complements and enhances monetary policy, while he added that Euro Area growth momentum has slowed markedly and more than we had previously been anticipating but is confident inflation will converge to target. Draghi also stated that side effects from monetary policy are growing and that we will have space to cut rates further. (Newswires)

Incoming ECB President Lagarde said the biggest hurdle the global economy is facing is protectionism, while she stated the US economy is in a very good place and Europe will be in good shape if there is a joint effort to steer the economy. (Newswires)

  • EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Sep) 45.6 vs. Exp. 47.3 (Prev. 47). (Newswires)
  • EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Sep) 52 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.5) 
  • EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Sep) 50.4 vs. Exp. 51.9 (Prev. 51.9) 
  • German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Sep) 41.4 vs. Exp. 44 (Prev. 43.5) 
  • German Markit Services Flash PMI (Sep) 52.5 vs. Exp. 54.3 (Prev. 54.8) 
  • German Markit Comp Flash PMI (Sep) 49.1 vs. Exp. 51.5 (Prev. 51.7)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Arabia's Khuraris and Abqaiaq facilities are to fully restore oil production early next week and are currently producing around 4.3mln BPD, according to sources. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said Russia are planning to cut September's oil output to comply with the OPEC+ deal. (Ifax)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said a meeting with North Korea's Kim Jong-un could come soon and said we will have to see what happens regarding a meeting with Iranian President Rouhani. Furthermore, Trump said he will discuss Iran in his UN speech tomorrow and that we have a lot of pressure on Iran, while he also commented he is not looking for a mediator on Iran and reiterated he has no meeting scheduled with Iranian President Rouhani. (Newswires)

US Envoy to Iran said the US seeks comprehensive negotiations with Iran that include discussions on missiles and terrorism. In related news, UK, Germany and France announced in a joint statement it is clear Iran is behind the Saudi Aramco attacks and reiterated their backing of the 2015 nuclear deal as well as their call on Iran to return to full compliance. (Newswires)

Iran President Rouhani said our message to the world is peace and stability, although there were earlier comments from a senior official that Iran will never yield to the US and the US should lift sanctions if it wants to reduce tensions. In other news, the Iranian Ambassador to the UK confirmed that the British tanker Stena Impero is free to leave Iran. (Newswires)

 

US

NY Fed have accepted USD 65.75bln of the USD 65.75bln in bids submitted to the overnight repo operation. (Newswires)

Fed's Williams (Voter, Neutral) said NY Fed's actions have their desired effect of reducing strains in the market and that repo operations are intended to keep EFFR in its target range. Williams added the bank was prepared for the liquidity issues and acted quickly and appropriate, while he noted the deadline for LIBOR is fast approaching and urged financial firms to act. (Newswires)

Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dovish Dissenter) said rate cuts and shifts in Fed’s tone has made policy more accommodative for now and that he is not seeing an intensification of yield curve inversion likely because the market sees more rate cuts ahead. Bullard also stated that rate cuts should help to lift inflation back to target and that decisions at the FOMC will be made meeting-by-meeting, while he added it is unclear whether other colleagues will support more rate cuts. (Newswires/WSJ)

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said the US economy is in a good place and that economic growth is being propelled by consumers. Daly also commented the case for keeping rates unchanged include concern over financial imbalances and expectations of rising inflation but cited the need to reach the inflation target as a reason why she supported the rate cut. (Newswires)

  • US Markit Manufacturing PMI Flash (Sep) 51.0 vs. Exp. 50.3 (Prev. 50.3). (Newswires) 
  • US Markit Services PMI Flash (Sep) 50.9 vs. Exp. 51.5 (Prev. 50.7) 
  • US Markit Comp Flash PMI (Sep) 51.0 (Prev. 50.7) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) traded higher as it received 10/15 tariff exemption requests on its Macbook Pro parts, Varian Medical Sciences (VAR) also received some tariff exemptions on its China produced radiotherapy components. Following positive China trade updates which put to sleep worries about the early Friday departure from the Chinese agriculture secretary, SOX traded higher however UBS note that despite the South Korean semiconductor exports falling drastically (-40% y/y), it was largely due to base effects and to stockpiling last year ahead of US-China trade worries and a public holiday. Boeing (BA) traded in the red as participants await an announcement from the US FAA regarding the progress of the 737-MAX jets, as many international aviator bodies are divided about the return of the jet. BA also have had to cover the costs induced by Icelandair for the grounding of their 737 MAX fleet, which consists of 6 jets, as part of an agreement. Sources also stated that BA’s acquisition of Embraer’s (ERJ) commercial airline business is subject to a full-scale EU antitrust investigation. American Express (AXP) caught a bid in the later session after announcing it is to repurchase up to 120mln shares (equates to 14.5% of the float) and an increase of its dividend. Facebook (FB) received some support for it’s Libra, from IBM (IBM), who are looking to collaborate with FB on digital currencies. According to FT, citing people familiar with the matter, AT&T(T) are facing further activist pressure from Elliott Management to divest some of its core assets, adding everything is potentially up for sale, including HBO. Equniix (EQIX) gained as it hired Uber’s (UBER) Head of Global Network and Software Platform as its CTO. Aptiv (APTIV) were higher following the announcement of an autonomous vehicle joint venture with Hyundai where both will hold a 50% stake in a JV valued at roughly USD 4bln. Materials were under pressure to start the week following a slew of metal name downgrades at JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs, with JPM double downgrading US Steel (X) following last week’s profit warning linked to a weakening global demand outlook. S&P 500 0% at 2992, NASDAQ-100 -0.1% at 7819, Dow Jones 0.1% at 26950.

The dismal EZ PMIs saw a flight into Treasuries and EGBs as hopes of a trough in the manufacturing sector were dissipated, where the decline begun to show it was feeding through into the services component. The mixed US PMIs failed to change the dial, however, going into the tail-end of the session yields did come off their lows and settled not far over 1bps lower across the curve. US T-note futures (Z9) settled 12+ ticks higher at 130-02+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 23rd September 2019: EZ PMI decline intensifies recession fears
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 23rd September 2019: EZ PMI decline intensifies recession fears

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities flat, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude up

* REAR VIEW: Concerns somewhat relieved from China leaving US early; EZ PMIs miss on all fronts, whilst US services disappoints; Fed’s Bullard, Williams, and ECB’s Draghi

* COMING UP: Data: German IFO, US Consumer Confidence, API Energy Inventories, New Zealand Trade. Events: UN General Assembly begins. Speakers: BoJ’s Kuroda, RBA’s Lowe, ECB’s de Galhau & de Guindos, Riksbank’s Ingves & Jansson, Norges Bank’s Nicolaisen & Matsen, BoE’s Carney. Auctions: German 4bln 2021 Schatz Auction, UK 0.5bln I/L 2048 Guilt Action, US 40bln 2yr Auction.

 

* US/CHINA: The US described recent talks as 'productive', while China has framed them as 'constructive'; the two sides agreed to keep communicating and have begun discussing details of the next round of trade talks in October. The NY Times explains China's cancelled visits to US farms out of concern that it would turn into a media circus and give the misimpression that China was trying to meddle in American domestic politics, rather than a result of trade negotiations. Meanwhile, US President Trump said that he was seeking a 'complete' trade deal, and that China just buying US agriculture was not enough, and again stated that he did not think that a trade deal was needed before the 2020 elections.

* TRADE COMMENT: The latest talks have provided no indication that progress has been made on the core issues (of IP theft, forced technology transfers, subsidies for state firms, for instance). There, of course, has been some goodwill gestures (US suspending tariff implementation on PRC 70th anniversary, China upping purchases of some US agriculture; some also point to Trump suspending tariffs on some goods that will have affected US consumers over the holiday season, though this seems more a cynical attempt to prevent self-harm, analysts have said), which are a positive, and President Trump will probably wave trade deals with Japan and India this week, with possible signals of a quick trade deal between the US/UK; but the market wants to see progress on US/China front, and on US/Europe (autos particularly) before it can begin to discount higher SPX multiples, brokers have said.

* US MARKIT PMI FLASH: Markit's flash September PMI surveys for the US surprised to the upside, with the manufacturing print rising to 51.0, against an expectation for an unchanged 50.3; the services gauge softened, against an expectation it would rise (50.9 against an expected 51.5). Markit explained the recent deterioration has been a further spill-over of the trade-led slowdown in manufacturing to the service sector. The survey indicates that businesses continue to struggle against the headwinds of trade worries and elevated uncertainty about the outlook, Markit said, noting that although picking up slightly, the overall rate of growth in September remained among the weakest since 2016, commensurate with GDP rising in Q3 at a subdued annualized rate of approximately  1.5%, while also warning that, at current levels, the employment index was indicative of non-farm payroll growth falling below 100,000. Meanwhile, Markit said that price pressures have meanwhile also eased, with both input costs and average selling prices for goods and services dropping again in September, painting a picture of the weakest corporate inflationary pressures for a decade.

* EUROZONE ADVANCED SEPTEMBER PMI: The composite fell to 50.4, against expectations for an unchanged reading of 51.9; the manufacturing print fell to 45.6 from 47.0, while the services PMI fell from 53.5 to 52. Markit said that a key development in recent months has been the broadening out of the deterioration beyond manufacturing. Pantheon Macroeconomics, however, said the services PMI through Q3 as a whole was 52.9, a trivial 0.2ppts lower versus Q2 2019, and still above the average for Q4 2018 and Q1 2019; "We concede that today’s data add fuel to the idea that a recession in manufacturing is now about to drag the economy as a whole down, but we need a bit more evidence to make this our base case," the consultancy said, "meanwhile for markets, the key story also is that policymakers are much more likely to respond with force, both fiscal and monetary, than to sit idle. How effective this 'put' is very difficult to say, but it’s there."

* GERMANY ADVANCED SEPTEMBER PMI: The composite PMI fell beneath 50, and into contraction territory (49.1 vs an expected 51.5 from 51.7). The manufacturing gauge fell further, to 41.4 from 43.5; the services component weakened to 52.5 from 54.8. Analysts said the data provided further signs that Germany is facing a technical recession in Q3, after the GDP contraction in Q2, as global trade conflicts and the stand-off between the EU and US weighs.

* EUROZONE INFLATION EXPECTATION SLIDE: Following the release of the advance September PMI data, long-term Eurozone inflation expectations fell to 1.2258%, to levels seen just before the ECB's September policy meeting.

* FED: Fed’s 50bp dissenter, Bullard said the rate cuts by the Fed should help to lift inflation back to its 2% target, but the “jury is still out” and that he thinks the bank will miss its 2% target this year and next (on Friday, he put one of his causes for dissent as Core and headline PCE running between 40 and 60 bps beneath target). On further rate cuts, Bullard said the decisions will be made meeting by meeting and that he was unclear whether other colleagues will support more rate cuts; the latest dot plots showed 7/17 members forecasting one further cut this year, Bullard being one of them. Bullard noted that the shift in the Fed’s tone has made policy more accommodative and that he is not currently seeing an intensification of yield curve inversion, likely because the market sees further rate cuts; Bullard adds, the dissenters reflect the high level of uncertainty at the Fed on how to assess the economy. On the repo-operation, Bullard feels the Fed reacted appropriately, medium term solution to trouble in the repo-market would be a new permanent facility at the fed. When asked about potential expansion of balance sheet to avoid further operations, says “it is not completely clear that volatility was a result of a shortage in the reserves system”. NY Fed President Williams spoke on the operations, saying the actions have seen the desired effect of reducing strains in the market; today’s operation was under subscribed (65.75bln accepted / USD 75bln offered), suggesting the liquidity drought in the repo market is potentially subsiding. Williams mentioned the operations are intended to keep EFFR in its target range and that the NY bank was prepared for the liquidity issues and acted quickly and appropriately. Williams also urged on changing LIBOR, saying the deadline for LIBOR is fast approaching and has urged financial firms to act, warning that if participants continue to structure products off of LIBOR thinking the Fed will delay its planned removal of the rate, they are mistaken.

* ECB’S DRAGHI’S (FINAL) TESTIMONY: Mainly reiterated the remarks made at his presser on September 12th, that EZ growth momentum has slowed markedly and more than had previously been anticipated. Draghi said the longer the weakness in manufacturing persists, the greater the risks that other sectors of the economy will be affected by the slowdown; comments made just a few hours after the further decline in the EZ Markit PMIs (flash), which saw both services and manufacturing miss expectations. Draghi noted that recent data and forward-looking data, such as new export orders in manufacturing, don’t show convincing signs of a rebound in growth soon and the balance of risks to the growth outlook remains tilted to the downside. Draghi took time to highlight that market expectations of inflation over the medium-term were inconsistent with the ECB’s target.

* BREXIT: The UK Supreme Court ruling on the legality of the Government's prorogation of Parliament is set to be announced on Tuesday at 10:30 BST; Foreign Secretary Raab has indicated that the government would abide by the ruling, but has not ruled-out the possibility of Parliament being prorogued again.

* UK/US TRADE: UK PM Johnson and US President Trump agree to strike UK/US trade deal by July 2020, with the two possibly publicly committing to the timeframe on Tuesday at the UN meetings in NY. The speed is likely to be influenced by the high risk of the US presidential election in November, where it may be harder for the UK to strike a deal under a Democrat administration, who have not expressed similar enthusiasm as Trump to strike a deal.

* WTI (X9) SETTLED USD 0.55 HIGHER AT USD 58.64/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLED USD 0.49 HIGHER AT USD 64.77/BBL: Crude reversed gains on Monday, as demand concerns re-surface after grim Eurozone flash PMI data for September raise the odds of a recession in Germany, stemming from the oil intensive manufacturing sector. Russian Energy Minister Novak affirmed that Russia will be cutting September’s oil output to ensure OPEC+ compliance, although this had little sway on Brent given Russia is already compliant, despite a marginal increase in August production. While Saudi officials have been guiding the market towards full normalisation of oil production by the end of the month (sources said on Monday that Khurais and Abqaiq could be restored to full production as soon as next week), contractors and insiders have reportedly suggested that repairing the Abqaiq plant might take months, which analysts say would likely put some upside into crude prices, particularly given that we are around 7% off the highs seen last week in wake of the recent attacks. The Saudis have been keen to reiterate that no customer shipments have yet been missed. Elevated risk in the region is also contributing to higher crude prices on Monday, analysts said. ING has said that the approximately USD 5/bbl risk premium that the market is pricing in seems fair, assuming we do see a return to pre-attack levels before the end of this month, adding that the global oil balance continues to tighten, which should offer further support to prices in the coming months. But ING does warn, however, that any strength will likely be short-lived, given that the supply outlook over 2020 continuing to look bearish. The latest US energy inventory expectations see crude stocks -0.8mln bbls, distillates -1.3mln bbls, gasoline +0.03mln bbls; Genscape’s flyover sees Cushing stocks +2.8mln bbls.

* SAUDI-IRAN: US President Trump has said that he has no plans to meet his Iranian counterpart Rouhani on the side-lines of the UN General Assembly, this week. Trump was keen to reiterate that he was flexible on talks. US Envoy for Iran Brian Hook later said the US is seeking comprehensive negotiations with Iran that include discussions on missile development and terrorism. Iran has previously ruled that talks could not take place without the lifting of sanctions, and the US returning to the 2015 JCPOA, as well as a USD 15bln credit line. 

* THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: The US will sell USD 40bln of new 2-year notes (Tue), USD 41bln of new 5-year notes (Wed), and USD 32bln of new 7-year notes; desks note there will be around USD 89bln of cash in the week, including USD 80bln of redemptions, and USD 9bln of coupons; this week, the Fed will buy USD 1.625bln in the 2-3 year sector (Thu), and USD 2.23bln on 3-5 year sector (Fri). Analysts at BMO said the latest yield move back from the bullish extremes should serve as at least a decent concession on an outright basis for all three auctions, though the persistent flatness of the curve leaves relative value asymmetrically benefitting shorter dated Treasuries.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 12+ TICKS HIGHER AT 130-02+. The dismal EZ PMIs saw a flight into Treasuries and EGBs as hopes of a trough in the manufacturing sector were dissipated, where the decline begun to show it was feeding through into the services component. The mixed US PMIs failed to change the dial, however, going into the tail-end of the session yields did come off their lows and settled not far over 1bps lower across the curve.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0% at 2992, NASDAQ-100 -0.1% at 7819, Dow Jones 0.1% at 26950

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.2%, Consumer Staples 0.4%, Energy 0.1%, Financials 0.2%, Health Care -0.6%, Industrials -0.2%, Information Technology 0.2%, Materials -0.3%, Telecommunication Services -0.4%, Utilities 0.1%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) traded higher as it received 10/15 tariff exemption requests on its Macbook Pro parts, Varian Medical Sciences (VAR) also received some tariff exemptions on its China produced radiotherapy components. Following positive China trade updates which put to sleep worries about the early Friday departure from the Chinese agriculture secretary, SOX traded higher however UBS note that despite the South Korean semiconductor exports falling drastically (-40% y/y), it was largely due to base effects and to stockpiling last year ahead of US-China trade worries and a public holiday. Boeing (BA) traded in the red as participants await an announcement from the US FAA regarding the progress of the 737-MAX jets, as many international aviator bodies are divided about the return of the jet. BA also have had to cover the costs induced by Icelandair for the grounding of their 737 MAX fleet, which consists of 6 jets, as part of an agreement. Sources also stated that BA’s acquisition of Embraer’s (ERJ) commercial airline business is subject to a full-scale EU antitrust investigation. American Express (AXP) caught a bid in the later session after announcing it is to repurchase up to 120mln shares (equates to 14.5% of the float) and an increase of its dividend. Facebook (FB) received some support for it’s Libra, from IBM (IBM), who are looking to collaborate with FB on digital currencies. According to FT, citing people familiar with the matter, AT&T(T) are facing further activist pressure from Elliott Management to divest some of its core assets, adding everything is potentially up for sale, including HBO. Equniix (EQIX) gained as it hired Uber’s (UBER) Head of Global Network and Software Platform as its CTO. Aptiv (APTIV) were higher following the announcement of an autonomous vehicle joint venture with Hyundai where both will hold a 50% stake in a JV valued at roughly USD 4bln. Materials were under pressure to start the week following a slew of metal name downgrades at JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs, with JPM double downgrading US Steel (X) following last week’s profit warning linked to a weakening global demand outlook.

* FX: USD higher today back above 98.50 heading towards the 99.00 handle, seeing a 98.84 high. The strength was driven by a weaker EUR following poor Eurozone PMI data sparking further worries about a potential EU recession. Initial DXY strength pared back slightly throughout the remainder of the session but still remained above 98.50 heading into Asia-Pac trade. ECB President Draghi added little new to the ECB statement, failing to add any direction to the single currency which now resides beneath the key 1.10 handle. GBP on the backfoot today trading relatively sideways with no new catalyst for the Pound as markets await tomorrow’s prorogation vote. Havens slightly firmer today, XAU remaining at highs despite a stronger buck, JPY and CHF also firmer following poor EZ PMI’s. NZD outperformed today ahead of RBNZ later in the week and trade data tonight, AUDUSD traded flat heading into the Asia session despite poor Australian PMI figures, however the initial losses were pared back, likely on further trade optimism. EM’s were mixed with BRL weaker following a larger deficit in its current account. MXN was also weaker despite strong retail sales as participants await Thursday’s Banxico rate decision, where 14/16 analysts surveyed by Reuters expect a 25bp cut, and the remaining two expecting a 50bp cut. ZAR was firmer against the buck trading in a range between 14.9634 -14.8400.

content:
• She supported rate cuts; when the headwinds blow, they have real effects
  • Cites lowering interest rates as a reason to why US economy continues to grow above trend
  • Tools are still very effective

subject: WTI (X9) settles USD 0.55 higher at USD 58.64/bbl; Brent (X9) settles USD 0.49 higher at USD 64.77/bbl
analysis_details: Crude traded choppy on Monday, as demand concerns re-surface after grim Eurozone flash PMI data for September raise the odds of a recession in Germany, stemming from the oil intensive manufacturing sector. Russian Energy Minister Novak affirmed that Russia will be cutting September’s oil output to ensure OPEC+ compliance, although this had little sway on Brent given Russia is already compliant, despite a marginal increase in August production. While Saudi officials have been guiding the market towards full normalisation of oil production by the end of the month (sources said on Monday that Khurais and Abqaiq could be restored to full production as soon as next week), contractors and insiders have reportedly suggested that repairing the Abqaiq plant might take months, which analysts say would likely put some upside into crude prices, particularly given that we are around 7% off the highs seen last week in wake of the recent attacks. The Saudis have been keen to reiterate that no customer shipments have yet been missed. Elevated risk in the region is also contributing to higher crude prices on Monday, analysts said. ING has said that the approximately USD 5/bbl risk premium that the market is pricing in seems fair, assuming we do see a return to pre-attack levels before the end of this month, adding that the global oil balance continues to tighten, which should offer further support to prices in the coming months. But ING does warn, however, that any strength will likely be short-lived, given that the supply outlook over 2020 continuing to look bearish. The latest US energy inventory expectations see crude stocks -0.8mln bbls, distillates -1.3mln bbls, gasoline +0.03mln bbls; Genscape’s flyover sees Cushing stocks +2.8mln bbls.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Euro frailer and Dollar firmer post-PMIs while Kiwi outperforms
content:
EUR, USD

The Euro remains on the backfoot but within its post-EZ PMI parameter of 1.0967-1025 after the flash metrics from the region disappointed across the board. IHS highlighted that Germany may not see any growth before year-end, whilst Q3 EZ GDP growth looks set to rise just 0.1%. Elsewhere, ECB President Draghi failed to provide any fresh catalysts given that his remarks were a reiteration of his post-ECB presser, whilst ECB-hawk Knot reiterated reservations regarding the Central Bank’s stimulus package. EUR/USD looks set to end the EU session closer to intraday lows, below 1.1000 mark after taking out Friday’s low and a Fib level around 1.0995-97 ahead of support at 1.0966 and 1.0950 (YTD low at 1.0924). Meanwhile, the Buck has derived some strength after Markit manufacturing topped estimates and composite improved, although services fell short of forecasts, there was an improvement from the prior. In light of the data, IHS noted that Q3 US GDP is seen rising at a subdued annualized rate of approximately 1.5%, and at current levels, the survey employment index is indicative of non-farm payroll growth falling below 100k. Further, Fed-voter Williams failed to provide much by way of impetus amid non-current monetary policy comments. DXY is set to end the EU session in the green around 98.70 ahead of the psychological 99.00 and resistance at 99.10 (vs. high of 98.84 and low of 98.44). On the docket State-side, traders will be on the lookout for Fed’s Bullard (voter, dove, dissenter) on monetary policy at 1800BST and Daly (non-voter, neutral) on supporting US economy in urban & rural communities.

 

GBP

Further losses for the Pound as participants eye the UK Supreme Court’s ruling on the legality of PM Johnson’s parliament prorogation, which is due tomorrow at 1030BST. If ruled against (as legal experts expect), then the PM could be forced to recall MPs back to parliament. Cable hovers near intraday lows and within a parameter of 1.2415-90 (100 DMA 1.2478) in light of some pressure from a firming Buck amid the aforementioned reasons.

 

NZD, AUD

Overall a positive day for the antipodeans, more so for the Kiwi ahead of trade data tomorrow and the RBNZ Monetary Policy Decision on Wednesday amid consensus for an unchanged Cash Rate at 1.00%, following its unexpected rate cut at its prior meeting, whilst the Shadow Board also recommends no change in policy. China/US trade news also seem to have supported the currencies after Chinese state media noted that talks are constructive, and that the cancelled China visit to US farms was not a sign of deteriorating talks. NZD/USD printed fresh intraday highs at 0.6283 after finding a base at 0.6250 whilst its Aussie counterpart remains flat above just 0.6750 and off highs (0.6780) as the AUD/NZD cross remains below the 1.08 level having traded within a 1.0775-1.0820 intraday parameter thus far. Looking ahead, RBA Governor Lowe is set to give an economic update tomorrow at 1055BST ahead of its Monetary Policy decision on October 1st, with participants, as ever on the lookout for hints as to whether the RBA will further ease. Ahead of the decision, analyst at Westpac have reiterated their call for a 25bps at the next RBA meeting amid the Fed rate cut and last week’s disappointing labour market report.

 

JPY, CHF

The safe havens are poised to the end session modestly firmer as USD/JPY remains below the 107.50 level after this morning’s downbeat EZ flash PMI release saw a flight to safety in which the pair touched a low of 107.32 (vs. high of 107.75). Meanwhile, EUR/CHF is set to close EU trade flat on the day but off an intra-day high of 1.0930 (50 DMA) vs. a base of just above 1.0850 (with support and YTD low at 1.0809). Looking ahead, the overnight session sees the release of Japanese PMIs ahead of comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda early doors at 0635BST.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 23rd September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has received tariff exclusion on certain Mac Pro Parts, with 10/15 requests accepted.
  • AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) is under pressure from Elliott Management to divest some of its assets. People familiar with the matter stated that everything is potentially up for sale, including HBO. (FT)
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is to have the 737 MAX progress explained by the US FAA as the international air regulators are divided about the return of the jet.

 

  • S&P Updates: NVR (NVR) (Consumer Discretionary/Household Durables) is to replace Jefferies Financial Group (JEF) (Financials/Multi-Sector Holdings) at the open on September 26th.
  • FT reports that Paul Singer’s Elliott Management is looking to raise up to USD 5bln in funding to prepare itself to profit from what it believes is an approaching downturn.
  • Barrons: Opioid crisis could hurt investors as a final resolution remains far off, adding (JNJ, TEVA, ENDP, MNK, ABT, MYL, MCK, CAH, ABC, WBA, CVS) are among the names which could potentially face further legal liabilities. Fast food stocks (YUM, MCD, CMG, WEN, QSR) could gain if consumer spending slows. CMCSA, DAL, FANG, FB, JNJ, MSFT: Among growth stocks that have core businesses to sail through economic turbulence. PG, K, KO, PEP, CL, KMG hold attractive yields. BYND, UBER, OSTK, susceptible to a short squeeze.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has been given tariff exclusion on certain Mac Pro Parts, with 10/15 requests accepted.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is to have the 737 MAX progress explained by the US FAA as the international air regulators are divided about the return of the jet. BA is to compensate Icelandair for its 737 MAX grounding costs, where it holds a fleet of 6 grounded 737 MAX jets. Also, Indonesian investigators have determined that design and oversight lapses played a key role in the jet crash, according to people familiar with the matter. (WSJ)
  • Dow Inc. (DOW) (Materials/Commodity Chemicals) has received a court order to pay USD 1.08bln for damages in 2012 caused by Nova Chemicals.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) announced a new Microsoft Dynamics 365- AI driven insight applications.
  • The Travelers Companies Inc. (TRV) (Financials/Property & Casualty Insurance) received approval from High Court of England and Wales to transfer its European business to Dublin.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) has reached a TV carriage agreement with AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) which includes ESPN on DirecTV and U-Verse, according to reports citing a Disney spokesperson.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) has been recently criticised by a ‘Grass Roots’ campaign which, has been revealed to be funded by competitors, Walmart (WMT), Oracle (ORCL) and Simon Property Group (SPG). (WSJ)
  • Chip names (INTC, WDC, TSMC, MU) – South Korea semiconductor exports declined 40% y/y, however UBS note that his is largely due to base effects, showing much of this weakness is not a sharp deterioration in export performance and that Sep 2018 exports were very strong as Korean companies likely frontloaded ahead of the lunar Chuseok holidays and US China trade wars. (UBS)
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) have received support from IBM (IBM) as it announced it is open to a collaboration with FB on digital currencies. (CNBC)
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) – A judge has ruled that the co. board must face a trial over CEO, Elon Musk’s pay, TSLA tried to dismiss the suit however the dismissal was ruled out. Elsewhere, Bernstein do not forecast an immediate path to boost TSLA’s model 3 gross margins, despite company optimism.
  • TSMC (TSM) (Information Technology/ Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) could start volume production of its 5nm chips in March 2020, according to sources. (DigiTimes).

S&P 500

subject: ECB President Draghi says we need a coherent economic strategy in the Euro area which complements and enhances monetary Policy; adds that Euro Area growth momentum has slowed markedly, and more than we had previously been anticipating
content:
• While the euro area services sector continues to be resilient, we should not be complacent about its capacity to remain robust to negative spillovers. The longer the weakness in manufacturing persists, the greater the risks that other sectors of the economy will be affected by the slowdown
  • Looking ahead, recent data and forward-looking indicators – such as new export orders in manufacturing – do not show convincing signs of a rebound in growth in the near future and the balance of risks to the growth outlook remains tilted to the downside
  • Although the likelihood of deflation remains limited, market expectations of inflation over the medium term are settling around values that are not consistent with our inflation aim.
  • In the context of this more protracted weakness of the euro area economy, both realised and projected inflation have been persistently below levels that are in line with the ECB Governing Council’s medium-term aim

Link to speech
analysis_details: • NOTE: Remarks from the Draghi are reiterations from his presser on September 12th, as such little reaction was seen across the market at the release of the speech

subject: WATCH LIVE: ECB President Draghi testimony to the European Parliament
content: • Link to video
analysis_details:
REMINDER: 

  • At the prior meeting (Sep 12), the ECB cut its deposit rate further into negative territory, with a reduction of 10bps to -0.50%
  • Policymakers opted to relaunch the APP at a clip of EUR 20bln p.m. from November with an open-ended nature
  • Furthermore, in terms of forward guidance on rates, the next rate hike will not occur until the inflation outlook “robustly converges to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2% within its projection horizon, and such convergence has been consistently reflected in underlying inflation dynamics
  • Bank also made the terms of its future TLTRO operations more favourable
  • Amid concerns surrounding bank profitability in the region (alongside the prolongation of negative rates), policymakers opted to introduce a tiering system which “exempts part of credit institutions’ excess liquidity holdings
  • During the presser, Draghi noted that incoming information indicates a more protracted weakness of the Eurozone economy

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 23rd September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Major European bourse are softer as risk sentiment slips on PMI prints
  • China’s agricultural delegation cancelled their farm trip at the US’ request, not due to trade talk difficulty
  • Saudi Arabia's Khuraris and Abqaiaq facilities are to fully restore oil production early next week; currently producing around 4.3mln BPD., according to sources
  • However, WSJ reports indicate that some experts believe it could take 8-months to restore Saudi production
  • EUR/USD is lower and core debt has been boosted on poor European Flash PMI metrics; as such the DXY is firmer
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Draghi & Lane, Fed’s Williams, Bullard & Daly

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed following the negative close last Friday on Wall St. amid temperamental US-China trade headlines, while the absence of Japanese markets also contributed to the lacklustre tone. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was positive with the index led higher by the commodity related stocks after gold advanced above the USD 1500/oz level and with oil underpinned by reports it could take 8 months for Saudi output to return to normal, while India’s NIFTY (+2.9%) outperformed again after the recent corporate tax cut announcement. Conversely, weakness in Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) dampened sentiment in the region with underperformance in the mainland as ongoing trade uncertainty overshadowed the liquidity efforts by the PBoC. This followed conflicting reports in which US President Trump stated Chinese agricultural purchases will not be enough and reiterated that he does not need a deal before the 2020 election although it was also reported the US granted temporary tariff exemptions on over 400 types of Chinese products, while China’s delegation cancelled its US farm visit but this was later attributed to concerns it could turn into a media circus or may be misconceived as meddling and was not due to a breakdown in trade talks.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 80bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0734 vs. Exp. 7.0828 (Prev. 7.0730)

Reports over the weekend stated the delegation of Chinese agriculture officials didn’t cancel the trip to US farms because of any new difficulty in the trade talks, but instead cancelled amid concerns it could turn into a media circus and to avoid misimpression China was trying to meddle in US domestic politics, while it was also said that the cancellation was done at the request of the US. (Newswires)

US and China deputy level talks were said to be constructive and the sides agreed to continue discussions on relevant issues, according to Chinese state media. (Newswires)

South Korea Sep. 1st-20th Trade Balance at surplus of USD 1.65bln, Exports fell 21.8% Y/Y and Imports fell 11.1% Y/Y. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US is still seeking to avoid war with Iran but added that additional troops being deployed to the region are for deterrence and defence. In related news, US positioned the USS Nitze destroyer armed with surface to air missiles, off the northeast coast of Saudi Arabia to cover the gap in Saudi Air Defences. (CBS)

Iran's Foreign Minister Zarif said US President Trump is determined not to get military involved but others around him are trying to drag him into it. (Axios)

Reports that Yemen's Houthi rebels said the Saudi-led coalition strike on Omran province killed 5 civilians, while Yemen have warned foreign diplomats Iran is preparing a follow-up strike to the missile and drone attack on Saudi’s oil facilities. (Al Masirah/WSJ)

Iranian Government spokesman says the legal steps are finished regarding the Stena Impero's release, though is not aware of the timing for its release., according to a report. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Legal experts expect the Supreme Court to rule against PM Johnson who would then be forced to recall MPs to Parliament. (Newswires) UK Foreign Secretary Raab has refused to rule out proroguing parliament for a second time if the Supreme Court rules in favour of PM Johnson's decision to suspend parliament. (BBC)

Unison (the UK's largest trade union) will push UK Opposition Leader Corbyn to back remain, rather than taking a neutral stance on Brexit. (Twitter)

ECB's Vasle said economic conditions are very complicated and there is likely a need for further ECB action. (Newswires)

 

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Sep) 45.6 vs. Exp. 47.3 (Prev. 47)

- EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Sep) 52 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.5)

- EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Sep) 50.4 vs. Exp. 51.9 (Prev. 51.9)

German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Sep) 41.4 vs. Exp. 44 (Prev. 43.5)

- German Markit Services Flash PMI (Sep) 52.5 vs. Exp. 54.3 (Prev. 54.8)

- German Markit Comp Flash PMI (Sep) 49.1 vs. Exp. 51.5 (Prev. 51.7)

French Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Sep) 50.3 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 51.1)

- French Markit Services Flash PMI (Sep) 51.6 vs. Exp. 53.2 (Prev. 53.4)

- French Markit Comp Flash PMI (Sep) 51.3 vs. Exp. 52.7 (Prev. 52.9)

Germany's VDMA forecast production drop of 2% for the engineering sector this year, with a further 2% decline next year amid trade tensions and increasing protectionism; does not expect an improvement soon. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are lower (Euro Stoxx 50 -1.0%), after disappointing PMI data stoked further concerns about the slowdown in Eurozone growth. The DAX (-1.2%) is the notable underperformer, slipping briefly below last week’s low and recent support at 12300, after German manufacturing PMI data pointed to the sector falling further into contractionary territory. Amid the risk off sentiment, utilities (+0.1%), consumer staples (+0.2%) and health care (unch.) sectors are supported, while materials (-1.6%), financials (-1.7%) and tech (-1.4%) are softer. Bucking the general risk tone are European airlines, including TUI (+7.5%), Ryanair (+1.1%) and easyJet (+3.5%), who are higher after rival Thomas Cook ceased trading activities and filed for bankruptcy. In terms of individual movers; William Hill (-4.0%) reversed early gains, despite premarket news that the Co. is looking for US broadcaster deals in an attempt to promote its brand. Elsewhere, K+S (-5.7%) sunk after being downgraded at Pareto Securities. Ocado (+0.2%) managed to reverse losses on triggered by news that the Co’s Chairman stated they “will go to any length” to protect their intellectual property, amid a court battle with a co-founder. Finally, ABN AMRO (-3.5%) is under pressure after being downgraded at Santander.

FX

EUR, USD - Further concerns about the European economy have weighed on the Euro in early trade as the latest flash PMIs out of the region deteriorated significantly vs. expectations. Germany’s release took EUR/USD below the 1.100 level with IHS noting that on its current trajectory, Germany may not see any growth before year-end, whilst VDMA added further pessimism to the German economic outlook. Further, the EZ release did little to immediately sway asset classes as participants anticipated a softer pan-release, but IHS highlighted that Q3 EZ GDP growth looks set to rise just 0.1%. Analysts at CapEco highlighted concerns regarding manufacturing contagion on the services sector whilst noting that a continuation in the employment component could lead to further easing in wages. Thus, the analysts believe that "there is little reason to think that GDP growth will pick up as the ECB and the consensus forecasts assume". EUR/USD took out Friday’s low and a Fib level around 1.0995-97 to print a base at 1.0967 ahead of support at 1.0966 and 1.0950 (YTD low at 1.0924). Next up, participants will be eyeing ECB President Draghi’s final testimony to the European Parliament at 1400BST. Meanwhile, the Buck has derived support in light of a weaker Single Currency as DXY extends its gains above 98.50 to a high of 98.84 and ahead of the psychological 99.00 and resistance at 99.10. On the docket State-side, traders will be on the lookout for a few Fed speaks including Williams (voter, neutral) at the US Treasury Market Conference at 1450BST, Bullard (voter, dove, dissenter) on monetary policy at 1800BST and Daly (non-voter, neutral) on supporting US economy in urban & rural communities.

GBP, CAD - Weaker on the day, albeit more on the back of a firmer USD with Brexit-watchers still on the lookout for the Supreme Court’s decision on PM Johnson’s parliament prorogation. If ruled against (as legal experts expect), then the PM could be forced to recall MPs back to parliament. Cable remains marginally softer below the 1.2450 level (vs. high of 1.2490) after finding a base at 1.2424, which marks the lowest since 17th September (although that day saw a low of 1.2393). The Loonie also takes a spot as a G10 laggard, but mostly pressured by a retreat in oil prices as the post-PMI sentiment seeped into the energy complex. USD/CAD hovers around the 1.3300 handle (vs. low of 1.3257) with resistance seen to the upside at 1.3305 (200 DMA), 1.3346 and the psychological 1.3350 levels.

CHF, JPY - Marginally firmer amid a weakening EUR and flights to safety post-EZ PMI with USD/JPY back below the 107.50 level to a low of 107.30 ahead of support at 107.10, whilst EUR/CHF trades flat on the day but fell from an intra-day high of 1.0930 (50 DMA) to a base just above 1.0850 (with support and YTD low at 1.0809). Attention remains on the 1.08 level amid the recent rise in SNB total sights deposits with TD noting that the data suggests the SNB may be defending the level.

AUD, NZD - The antipodeans remain above water with the Kiwi outperforming its Tasman-peer ahead of this week’s RBNZ Monetary Policy Decision amid consensus for an unchanged Cash Rate at 1.00%, following its unexpected rate cut at its prior meeting, whilst the Shadow Board also recommends no change in policy. The currencies seem to have also derived some support from the US-China trade saga with Chinese state media noting that talks are constructive, and that the cancelled China visit to US farms was not a sign of deteriorating talks. NZD/USD hovers near intra-day highs (0.6277) after finding a base at 0.6250 whilst its Aussie counterpart remains above 0.6750, albeit off highs (0.6780).

Israel Joint List party are to back center-left’s Benny Gantz to form a new government. (Newswires)

FIXED

An upbeat start to the week for the debt complex, with Bunds leading the charge having touched a high of 174.52 at best thus far equating to over a full point in upside, in wake of an abysmal slate of PMIs out of Europe. The bulk of the price action occurred on the poor German prints, which saw Manufacturing drop further into contractionary territory, Composite move under the 50 mark and services ever closer to this figure at 52.5. As is typical there was fairly limited reaction to the EZ wide metric as price action had already moved in anticipation of a softer flash prints. Moving to Gilts which are bid in sympathy with their EZ counterparts firmly above Friday’s high of 132.81 having reached 132.55 at best; price action for Gilts may derive some impetus from BoE’s Tenreyro speaking on Inflation but given the BoE’s hands remain tied until the conclusion of Brexit this may not be too instrumental. Moving across the pond to USTs which are also bid following European price action, a very quiet data slate ahead with only Flash PMIs of note (manufacturing Exp. in-line at 50.3; services firmer than Prev. at 51.5) similarly to the UK focus turns to Central Bank speak with Fed’s Williams and Bullard the highlights; prior to this, USTs currently just off of session highs at 130.08+ (+16 ticks).

COMMODITIES

Oil prices continued to come off its earlier highs, as focus shifted from the prospect of a more protracted disruption to Saudi Aramco supply than expected (which helped prices over the weekend) to concern over global growth, after more abysmal Eurozone PMI data triggered a bout of selling in the complex. Downside was exacerbated soon thereafter on source reports that Saudi Arabia's Khuraris and Abqaiaq facilities are to fully restore oil production early next week (form current production levels of around 4.3mln BPD), contrary to WSJ reports over the weekend that repairs could take up to 8 months. WTI Nov’ 19 futures slumped through last week’s lows around the USD 58/bbl handle, before finding a base at USD 57.40/bbl, while Brent Nov’ 19 fell below the USD 64/bbl handle, although last week’s USD 63.06 low is still some way off. Gold prices are higher, despite opening on the back foot (on weekend reports that Chinese agriculture officials didn’t end their US trip early due to trade talk difficulties) and a firmer buck, with negative risk sentiment exacerbated by the aforementioned Eurozone PMIs helping to lift the precious metal; spot gold continues to climb from its recent USD 1500/oz base. On the flip side, global demand concerns are keeping copper prices under pressure.

Saudi Arabia's Khuraris and Abqaiaq facilities are to fully restore oil production early next week; currently producing around 4.3mln BPD., according to sources. (Newswires)

Aramco is in emergency discussions with contractors and are offering premium rates for parts and repair work in an effort to resume output quickly amid concerns repairs may last many months instead of the maximum 10 weeks that was promised. Some ARAMCO board members were said to be horrified Co. communicated such optimistic assessments on returning output to normal, while technical experts shared the view with some Saudi officials that it could take 8 months. (WSJ/Newswires)

Saudi Aramco notified Japan's top oil distributor JXTG Nippon Oil & Energy regarding a potential change in shipments in which it wants to change the oil grade it supplies from light to heavy and medium beginning next month which reports suggest indicates ARAMCO is having a hard time restoring its production as quickly as it has promised. (Nikkei)

Total Port Arthur Texas refinery is raising production after storm Imelda, while Valero Port Arthur Texas refinery has resumed production of its crude unit and Exxon also restarted its Beaumont Texas Refinery large crude unit. (Newswires)

The Loonie also takes a spot as a G10 laggard, but mostly pressured by a retreat in oil prices as the post-PMI sentiment seeped into the energy complex. USD/CAD hovers around the 1.3300 handle (vs. low of 1.3257) with resistance seen to the upside at 1.3346 and the psychological 1.3350 levels.

CHF, JPY

Marginally firmer amid a weakening EUR and flights to safety post-EZ PMI with USD/JPY back below the 107.50 level to a low of 107.30 ahead of support at 107.10, whilst EUR/CHF trades flat on the day but fell from an intra-day high of 1.0930 (50 DMA) to a base just above 1.0850 (with support and YTD low at 1.0809). Attention remains on the 1.08 level amid the recent rise in SNB total sights deposits with TD noting that the data suggests the SNB may be defending the level.

AUD, NZD

The antipodeans remain above water with the Kiwi outperforming its Tasman-peer ahead of this week’s RBNZ Monetary Policy Decision amid consensus for an unchanged Cash Rate at 1.00%, following its unexpected rate cut at its prior meeting, whilst the Shadow Board also recommends no change in policy. The currencies seem to have also derived some support from the US-China trade saga with Chinese state media noting that talks are constructive, and that the cancelled China visit to US farms was not a sign of deteriorating talks. NZD/USD hovers near intra-day highs (0.6277) after finding a base at 0.6250 whilst its Aussie counterpart remains above 0.6750, albeit off highs (0.6780).

subject: Fixed: Debt surges higher ahead of Central Bank speakers
content: An upbeat start to the week for the debt complex, with Bunds leading the charge having touched a high of 174.52 at best thus far equating to over a full point in upside, in wake of an abysmal slate of PMIs out of Europe. The bulk of the price action occurred on the poor German prints, which saw Manufacturing drop further into contractionary territory, Composite move under the 50 mark and services ever closer to this figure at 52.5. As is typical there was fairly limited reaction to the EZ wide metric as price action had already moved in anticipation of a softer flash prints. Looking ahead, no data on the slate though comments from ECB’s Draghi initially at 14:00BST will be closely scrutinised for any further guidance. Moving to Gilts which are bid in sympathy with their EZ counterparts firmly above Friday’s high of 132.81 having reached 132.55 at best; price action for Gilts may derive some impetus from BoE’s Tenreyro speaking on Inflation but given the BoE’s hands remain tied until the conclusion of Brexit this may not be too instrumental. Moving across the pond to USTs which are also bid following European price action, a very quiet data slate ahead with only Flash PMIs of note (manufacturing Exp. in-line at 50.3; services firmer than Prev. at 51.5) similarly to the UK focus turns to Central Bank speak with Fed’s Williams and Bullard the highlights; prior to this, USTs currently just off of session highs at 130.08+ (+16 ticks).

subject: Unison (the UK's largest trade union) will push UK Opposition Leader Corbyn to back remain, rather than taking a neutral stance on Brexit
content: Via Twitter
analysis_details:
• Currently Opposition (& Labour) Leader Corbyn is backing a second referendum on Brexit, with an option to remain, but has not come out explicitly in support for remain. Since the Liberal Democrats came out in favour of remain last week, pledging to revoke article 50 and cancel Brexit, Labour have been bleeding support to them in the polls.
  • As such, pro-remain members within the Labour party have been pushing Corbyn to take a more pro-remain stance.
  • At the Labour Party Conference today, the debates on Brexit motions to start 3pm, Kier Starmer will have a speech at 5.10pm and immediately after votes on the parties strategy will take place, including on the party's Brexit stance.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

23rd September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed following the negative close last Friday on Wall St. amid the temperamental US-China trade headlines, while the absence of Japanese markets also contributed to the lacklustre tone. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was positive with the index led higher by the commodity related stocks after gold advanced above the USD 1500/oz level and with oil underpinned by reports it could take 8 months for Saudi output to return to normal, while India’s NIFTY (+2.2%) outperformed again after the recent corporate tax cut announcement. Conversely, weakness in Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.3%) dampened sentiment in the region with underperformance in the mainland as ongoing trade uncertainty overshadowed the liquidity efforts by the PBoC. This followed conflicting reports in which US President Trump stated Chinese agricultural purchases will not be enough and reiterated that he does not need a deal before the 2020 election although it was also reported the US granted temporary tariff exemptions on over 400 types of Chinese products, while China’s delegation cancelled its US farm visit but this was later attributed to concerns it could turn into a media circus or may be misconceived as meddling and was not due to a breakdown in trade talks.

FTSE 100

LSE (LSE LN) – Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) has reportedly asked HSBC (HSBA LN) and UBS (UBSG SW) to help it charm LSE shareholders after the GBP 32bln takeover approach by HKEX was rejected by the LSE board. HSBC was hired to advise HKEX on the process after the bank organised a meeting with city investors last week, the bank is likely to announce a move tomorrow, the Telegraph understands. (Telegraph)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Co. is to exit the mortgage lending business, as the co. looks to improve the profitability of its banking unit and conserve capital. (FT)

Ocado (OCDO LN) – Co. chairman noted that Co. “will go to any length” to protect its intellectual property amid a court battle with a co-founder. (Times)

BT (BT/A LN) – European football’s governing body, UEFA, has signalled to potential bidders that it will pout television rights for the Champions League around the middle of October. BT will be favourite to retain the deal, while rival Sky is expected to focus on original content and its UK full fibre broadband going forward. (Telegraph)

Ryanair (RYA LN) – Co. is under scrutiny for threatening disciplinary actions against pilots that have taken over four bouts of sick-leave in a year. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Marks & Spencer (MKS LN) – Co’s Finance Chief Humphrey Singer has decided to leave the Co., adding to investor concerns around the Co. after its relegation from the FTSE 100 earlier this month. (Telegraph)

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) – Co. has ceased trading with immediate effect, said the UK Civil Aviation Authority, after the company failed to secure a further GBP 200mln in funding. The co. has now filed for bankruptcy. (Sky News)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 23rd September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were mixed following the negative close last Friday on Wall St. amid temperamental US-China trade headlines
  • Trump reiterated he does not need a deal before the 2020 election and is not interested in a limited China deal
  • Reports suggest that repair work for Saudi to return to normal oil output levels could take much longer than expected
  • US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US is still seeking to avoid war with Iran but added that additional troops being deployed to the region are for deterrence and defence
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Flash PMIs, ECB’s Draghi & Lane; Fed’s Williams, Bullard & Daly

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed following the negative close last Friday on Wall St. amid temperamental US-China trade headlines, while the absence of Japanese markets also contributed to the lacklustre tone. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was positive with the index led higher by the commodity related stocks after gold advanced above the USD 1500/oz level and with oil underpinned by reports it could take 8 months for Saudi output to return to normal, while India’s NIFTY (+2.2%) outperformed again after the recent corporate tax cut announcement. Conversely, weakness in Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.3%) dampened sentiment in the region with underperformance in the mainland as ongoing trade uncertainty overshadowed the liquidity efforts by the PBoC. This followed conflicting reports in which US President Trump stated Chinese agricultural purchases will not be enough and reiterated that he does not need a deal before the 2020 election although it was also reported the US granted temporary tariff exemptions on over 400 types of Chinese products, while China’s delegation cancelled its US farm visit but this was later attributed to concerns it could turn into a media circus or may be misconceived as meddling and was not due to a breakdown in trade talks.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 80bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0734 vs. Exp. 7.0828 (Prev. 7.0730)

US President Trump said he has an amazing relationship with Chinese President Xi but are having a little spat, while he added Chinese agricultural purchases will not be enough and that he wants a complete deal. Trump reiterated he does not need a deal before the 2020 election and is not interested in a limited China deal, while he added China is 'eating' the tariffs. (Newswires)

Montana Farm Bureau said the Chinese delegation cancelled its US farm visit to Montana and its agriculture officials are returning to China sooner than expected. However, reports over the weekend stated the delegation of Chinese agriculture officials didn’t cancel the trip because of any new difficulty in the trade talks but instead cancelled amid concerns it could turn into a media circus and to avoid misimpression China was trying to meddle in US domestic politics, while it was also said that the cancellation was done at the request of the US. (Newswires)

US and China deputy level talks were said to be constructive and the sides agreed to continue discussions on relevant issues, according to Chinese state media. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Legal experts expect the Supreme Court to rule against PM Johnson who would then be forced to recall MPs to Parliament. (Newswires) UK Foreign Secretary Raab has refused to rule out proroguing parliament for a second time if the Supreme Court rules in favour of PM Johnson's decision to suspend parliament. (BBC)

UK Brexit proposals reportedly don’t amount to a legally operational solution and fall short of satisfying objective of backstop, according to reports citing a leaked document. In related news, the UK is said to have responded that the ideas put forward to avoid a hard border are serious and workable, while it is focussed on actually getting a deal in the room and trust the EU Commission will do the same. (Newswires)

ECB's Vasle said economic conditions are very complicated and there is likely a need for further ECB action. (Newswires)

FX

 

Price action was relatively quiet in which the DXY gave back some of Friday’s gains which had been spurred amid a deterioration in risk sentiment and amid broad losses in its major counterparts, including EUR/USD which briefly tested 1.1000 to downside where it eventually rebounded from. GBP/USD was lacklustre beneath 1.2500 with UK PM Johnson pessimistic on reaching a full “legally operable” deal covering the Irish border at next month’s EU summit and amid reports the UK’s proposals fell short of satisfying the objectives of the backstop. USD/JPY found reprieve after support held at 107.50 and was helped by some early safe-haven outflows, while antipodeans recovered some lost ground following a stronger than expected reference rate setting, with mild outperformance in NZD heading into this week’s RBNZ rate meeting where the central bank is expected to stand pat and in which the New Zealand Shadow Board also recommended no change in policy.

Israel Joint List party are to back center-left’s Benny Gantz to form a new government. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed with early advances seen in oil prices after reports that repair work for Saudi to return to normal output levels could take much longer than expected with some experts and officials anticipating as long as 8 months vs. the 10-week timeframe ARAMCO projected, although oil prices are off intraday highs amid the cautious overnight risk tone and as Texas refineries begin to ramp up their production in the aftermath of storm Imelda. Elsewhere, gold was steady as it took a breather from Friday’s gains, while copper traded lacklustre amid the mixed risk sentiment and underperformance in its largest buyer China.

Baker Hughes (Sep 13): Oil rigs -14 at 719, Nat Gas rigs -5 at 148, Total rigs -18 at 868. (Newswires)

Aramco is in emergency discussions with contractors and are offering premium rates for parts and repair work in an effort to resume output quickly amid concerns repairs may last many months instead of the maximum 10 weeks that was promised. Some ARAMCO board members were said to be horrified Co. communicated such optimistic assessments on returning output to normal, while technical experts shared the view with some Saudi officials that it could take 8 months. (WSJ/Newswires)

Saudi Aramco notified Japan's top oil distributor JXTG Nippon Oil & Energy regarding a potential change in shipments in which it wants to change the oil grade it supplies from light to heavy and medium beginning next month which reports suggest indicates ARAMCO is having a hard time restoring its production as quickly as it has promised. (Nikkei)

Total Port Arthur Texas refinery is raising production after storm Imelda, while Valero Port Arthur Texas refinery has resumed production of its crude unit and Exxon also restarted its Beaumont Texas Refinery large crude unit. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US is still seeking to avoid war with Iran but added that additional troops being deployed to the region are for deterrence and defence. In related news, US positioned the USS Nitze destroyer armed with surface to air missiles, off the northeast coast of Saudi Arabia to cover the gap in Saudi Air Defences. (CBS)

 

Iran's Foreign Minister Zarif said US President Trump is determined not to get military involved but others around him are trying to drag him into it. (Axios)

 

Yemen Houthis are reportedly to stop targeting Saudi territories and expect those targeting Yemen to announce something similar. However, there were separate reports that Yemen's Houthi rebels said the Saudi-led coalition strike on Omran province killed 5 civilians, while Yemen have warned foreign diplomats Iran is preparing a follow-up strike to the missile and drone attack on Saudi’s oil facilities. (Al Masirah/WSJ)

 

US

Treasuries caught a bid in the tail-end of the session and going into the weekend (after trading mainly sideways) in the latest risk-off flows as the Chinese delegation announced it was leaving the US earlier than it had anticipated. There was some support for the TPLEX earlier, taking cues from Bunds, after Germany announced new climate budget plans would be financed via taxes, otherwise little else had much effect on Friday. At settlement yields were lower by around 3bps with spreads mixed. US T-note futures (z9) settled 3 ticks higher at 129-22.

Fed's Bullard (Voter, Dovish Dissenter Voted 50bps Cut) forecasts one more rate cut in 2019 and commented that the Fed should not market signals of a potential recession. (Newswires)

Fed's Rosengren (Voter, Hawkish Dissenter) said building permits and initial claims for unemployment insurance are not signalling a recession, while he also stated PPI and Dallas Trimmed Mean inflation measures are firm and does not see another rate cut unless the financial conditions change. (Fox)

Fed's Williams (Voter, Neutral) questioned the hesitance of banks in the repo market and suggested the need to focus on how the market functions and not the level of reserves at the Fed. (FT)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said he has pencilled in no more rate cut this year and one next year, while he added the Fed should seriously examine plans to allow balance sheet increase with the increase in demand for reserves. Kaplan also stated he is not opposed to nor leaning towards further rate cuts this year and will be open minded and will not prejudge, while he earlier suggested he would rather take modest, limited action and that if we wait to see evidence of a weak consumer, the Fed will have waited too long. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: US granted temporary tariff exemption on over 400 types of Chinese products; Chinese delegation cancelled its US farm visit although it was later reported this was to avoid a media circus and misconceptions
content:
Fosun International (656 HK) - Co. said it is disappointing Thomas Cook in which it is the biggest shareholder in was unable to find a solution after the UK-listed travel firm ceased trading. (Newswires)

HKEX (388 HK) - Co. has reportedly hired advisers to sway LSE investors. (Newswires)

Protests - Protesters and polices clashed again over the weekend during a 16th week of protests. (Newswires)

Leisure - Less than 30% of Hong Kong hotel rooms have been booked for Golden Week. (Newswires)

Other News - China Jan-Aug throughput rose 5% Y/Y and cargo throughout increased 7.9% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Trade

US President Trump said he has an amazing relationship with Chinese President Xi but are having a little spat, while he added Chinese agricultural purchases will not be enough and that he wants a complete deal. Furthermore, Trump reiterated he does not need a deal before the 2020 election and is not interested in a limited China deal, while he added China is 'eating' the tariffs. (Newswires)

US granted temporary tariff exemption on over 400 types of Chinese products after having received more than 1,100 exclusion requests made by companies and other entities in US. (Newswires)

Montana Farm Bureau said the Chinese delegation cancelled its US farm visit to Montana and its agriculture officials are returning to China sooner than expected. However, reports over the weekend stated the delegation of Chinese agriculture officials didn’t cancel the trip because of any new difficulty in the trade talks but instead cancelled amid concerns it could turn into a media circus and to avoid misimpression China was trying to meddle in US domestic politics. (Newswires)

US and China deputy level talks were said to be constructive and the sides agreed to continue discussions on relevant issues, according to Chinese state media. (Newswires)

Data Recap - Hong Kong CPI (Aug) Y/Y 3.5% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 3.3%). (Newswires)
